newsitem.title: CHINA: China typhoon death toll climbs to 14.
newsitem.headline: China typhoon death toll climbs to 14.

text.p: The death toll from Typhoon Willie, which slammed into China's southern island province of Hainan last week, has climbed to 14, officials said on Monday.
About 11 people were killed in Wenchang county, an official told Reuters by telephone, but declined to give further details.
Two people were killed and 25 injured in Haikou, capital of Hainan, state media has said.
In Xiongshan county, the typhoon electrocuted one person and caused losses worth 500 million yuan ($60.2 million), a local official said.
About 26,700 people were marooned by floods when about 100 metres (328 ft) of dykes were washed away in Xiongshan county, the official said.
"The storm is the worst to hit the county in 20 years," he said, adding about 20 military vessels had been deployed to rescue fishermen.
The typhoon injured eight people in Xuwen county in neighbouring Guangdong province last week and caused economic losses worth 800 million yuan ($96.4 million), a local official said.
In Hanoi, meteorological officials said Willie had weakened to a tropical low pressure after it landed in Vietnam's northern and north central provinces on Sunday evening.
Earlier this month, Typhoon Sally killed at least 133 people when it thrashed southern provinces of China's Guangdong and Guangxi.
Floods that swept across central and southern China in July killed at least 2,700 people and left hundreds of thousands homeless.
